awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Smart Control Automation and Learning for Energy
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a commercial building management system that uses model predictive control for small to mid-sized commercial building owners to help them flexibly manage increasingly complex energy codes and prices. This technology uses machine learning to automate costly aspects of advanced building control, and eliminating complexity, frustration, and expense for leanly staffed building owners who are attempting to save money, meet code, reduce carbon footprint and adapt to rapidly changing energy prices. The proposed approach significantly reduces the setup time, the amount of training data, and the compute time needed for the technology to converge on accurate models and predictions using building thermal dynamics. These improvements reduce the controller costs without sacrificing accuracy. This technology will simplify the setup and implementation process for under-represented segments in the building automation, efficiency and model-based controls market starting with K-12 schools. This simplification has several distinct societal and environmental benefits including: increased energy and demand charge savings, increased energy efficiency, improved environmental footprint, increased job creation for building controls technicians, improved resiliency, and additional educational opportunities for K-12 families and communities.

This SBIR Phase I project develops a technology capable of building efficiency control.  The innovation employs a hybrid approach based on constrained deep learning tools that build on physical knowledge of building systems and architecture, thereby making use of sampling data while producing physics-consistent accuracy in modeling and control predictions. Specifically, the project team hopes to converge on an architecture that can more reliably and accurately manage energy use and occupant comfort compared to state of the art control approaches. The project team also aims to demonstrate a significant reduction in heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC)-driven peak system demand in target buildings while keeping instrumentation, labor, and data costs per building to an affordable cost for the target market.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this SBIR Phase I project was to leverage machine learning (ML) to generate a predictive building physics model that can be used by a building management system (BMS) in order to optimize heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) performance and comfort in commercial buildings.

Schools, in particular, struggle with rising energy costs, outdated infrastructure, and the challenge of maintaining comfortable learning environments on a fixed budget. Our solution reduces energy waste, improves HVAC efficiency, and lowers energy costs - all without requiring major equipment upgrades, or, significant energy modeling expertise.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its novel approach to integrating ML and model predictive control (MPC) with existing HVAC controls. During Phase I, Community Energy Labs (CEL) successfully developed and tested a prototype that analyzes real-time data, building characteristics, and usage patterns to model and predict heating and cooling needs. This predictive model is then implemented in a software solution that can autonomously adjust HVAC settings (see Figure 1). The system improves efficiency and reduces peak demand through using the predictive model to anticipate energy use, utility prices and indoor air temperature and to make real-time adjustments in how often and how long mechanical equipment runs - such as letting rooms 'coast' at a comfortable indoor air temperature.

Our tests demonstrated that schools could shift at least 15% of HVAC energy use from expensive peak electricity pricing hours to lower-cost periods while reducing coincident peak demand by 20-30%. These findings validate the feasibility of using low-cost, data-driven modeling and automation to optimize energy use in commercial buildings.

The broader impacts of this work are significant, particularly for commercial building operators that struggle with fixed maintenance budgets and increasingly expensive and complex utility rates. By automating the management of complex energy prices (such as time of use and demand charges) the innovation in this SBIR saves money on bills, but also saves time.  Automation eliminates the need for maintenance staff to spend 5-8 hours per week adjusting thermostat settings in order to save on energy bills.

Additionally the accumulation of operational efficiencies from this innovation redirect bill savings toward educational resources that improve US competitiveness. Specifically, the 100,000+ K-12 schools in the U.S. are the largest energy consumers in the public sector. Within schools, HVAC energy accounts for 46% of this total energy consumption. A powerful, time-saving solution that integrates with existing BMS and thermostats could free up millions of dollars that could be reinvested into curriculum and facilities that support student achievement.

In addition to cost savings, real-time energy management enhances US grid resilience by reducing stress on power systems during periods of peak demand. In 2019, the US commercial sector consumed 18.18 quadrillion Btu of primary energy, a 72% increase from 1980, with operational energy making up 80-90% of a building's life cycle energy consumption. Few recognize how much of that operational energy burden comes from institutions with aging buildings and dwindling budgets.

Education alone makes up 14% of US Commercial floorspace, second only to office space, with the average age of a US school building in 1998 being 42 years old. At scale, the flexible coordination of operational electrical end loads has potential to provide 1393 PJ (1.32 quads) of energy efficiency and ~200 GW of peak flexibility to the grid,resulting in $15 billion per year in benefits to U.S.ratepayers. But getting there means we must provide viable means for small and mid-sized commercial building operators to engage and adopt grid-interactive efficient building (GEB) technologies such as the concept carried out on this project.

This technology also creates economic and job opportunities through a new class of facilities management and maintenance roles that incorporate software, sensor deployment, and machine learning. Building on the success of Phase I, CEL is now working with commercial building owners to expand real-world testing and refine the system for broader deployment. Our ongoing research aims to improve accuracy, enhance user interfaces, and ensure seamless integration with existing building and HVAC infrastructure. We plan to publish findings from upcoming field trials and to collaborate with schools, utilities, and policy makers to maximize the impact of predictive energy management across diverse building types.

This project demonstrated that schools and other commercial buildings can achieve meaningful energy savings and operational efficiencies through advanced automation. By making intelligent, data-driven energy management accessible, MPC+ML technology has the potential to transform how buildings interact with the power grid - lowering costs and contributing to a more resilient energy future.
